instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.SMC_TDI: What is SMC_TDI? SMC_TDI is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SMC_TDO: What is SMC_TDO? SMC_TDO is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I'm getting stuck on this board. It has:
• 3V42
• <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
• <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>
• <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
• <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
• <SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL>
• <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>

Does not have:
• <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
• <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>.
• <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 

I've been getting through these missing SLP boards pretty smoothly lately but this one is getting me. Any help would be appreciated. And let me know if there's other information I left off that would be helpful.

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: History of the board, water? Check <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> for pulses, it may power cycle very quickly.

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Was this a drop or a spill, and if a spill, on what area?

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I'm assuming you meant <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> but let me know if I'm wrong. <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> is completely dead. Stays at 0V.

The board was cleaned before I got it but from what I can tell, it definitely looks like a liquid spill up by the CPU, to the top and right of it. Beyond that, the board looks pretty decent.

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I realize SLP issues are tricky enough when they're right in front of you, let alone across the globe, but do you have any other suggestions for this one?

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Check power to RTC circuit and 32KHz from clock chip

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Is the SMC in the "right" mode, check the <SIGNAL>SMC_TDI</SIGNAL> <SIGNAL>SMC_TDO</SIGNAL> etc stuff. you can have a green light and still get shit on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> if the SMC is trolling you.

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: What is the right mode the SMC should be in when it is on and working properly?

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Any updates? Curious. In a similar boat.

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Not yet. This one got cycled to the back of the line. I'll be sure to update this thread though when I get back to it.
